2 kids, at least 1 girl name Lilia with probability
, what is the probability both are girls
L=at least 1 child (same as at least 1 girl, cuz only girl can be named Lilia) named Lilia
P(L|BB)=given BB, probability of at least 1 girl named Lilia = 0
P(L|BG)=given GB, or GB, probability at least 1 girl name Lilia
P(L|GG)=given GG, at least 1 girl name Lilia
compare result from (a) question about 2 children, what is probaility=1/3 of 2 girls if 1 was a girl, suprisingly knowing the name dramatically improves chances.

To explain this, in (a) knowing 1 of the kid is a girl narrow down the sample space to {BG,GB,GG}, and all options are equally likely. But knowing 1 of the girl's name is Lilia means the 3 options are no longer equally likely. Note that P(L|BG)=P(L|GB)=a < P(L|GG)=2a-a*a. If both kids are girls, it is more likely to name 1 of the girls Lilia.
family has 2 children, saw 1 of them is a G, what is probability both are girls.
rephrase the problem, a family has 2 children, choose 1 of them randomly and find out she's a girl, what is the probability that both are girls?
A=event that randomly chosen kid is a girl
P(A|BB)=given BB, probability of picking a girl = 0
P(A|BG)=given BG, probability of picking a girl = 1/2
P(A|GB)=given GB, probability of picking a girl = 1/2
P(A|GG)=given GG, probability of picking a girl = 1

compare to result from (2 children, given at least 1 girl, probability of both are girls=1/3), vs now 2 children, choose 1 at random and find the kid is a girl, the probability both are girls is 1/2.  The 2 problem looks very similar, note that P(A|GG) is no longer equal to P(A|BG) or P(A|GB).
toss unfair coin repeatedly, with P(H)=p, ends when HH, or TT is observed. win if HH, loose if TT.
let n=number of tosses to win→nth toss = H, n-1 th toss = H
P(win in n tosses)=P(win in 2 toss)+P(win in 3 toss)+...P(win in n tosses)
